title: Conflict Partnership
description: Reflect on your overall approach to conflict as a team

questions.text: I feel we're on the same team, even when we disagree.

therapeutic.rationale: Same-team mentality transforms conflict from adversarial to collaborative. When you're both trying to solve a problem rather than defeat each other, resolution comes easier.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel like teammates during conflict, explore what creates the adversarial feeling. Competition? Blame? Understanding helps shift the dynamic.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of teamwork during disagreement creates collaborative conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you feel like teammates or opponents during disagreements?

questions.text: Conflict doesn't make me doubt that we're good together.

therapeutic.rationale: Secure couples can disagree without questioning compatibility. When conflict triggers relationship doubt, even small disagreements become threatening.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If conflict triggers compatibility doubts, explore what would provide reassurance. Sometimes the conflict pattern, not the conflict itself, creates doubt.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence in your compatibility despite conflict creates security.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does conflict make you doubt your relationship? What would help?

questions.text: I trust that my partner wants to work things out with me.

therapeutic.rationale: Trusting your partner's commitment to resolution provides security. Even during conflict, knowing they want to work it out sustains engagement.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If trust in commitment to resolution is low, explore what creates that doubt. Actions during conflict? Follow-through afterward? Identifying the source helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual trust in each other's commitment to resolution creates secure conflict.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Do you trust your partner wants to work things out? What affects that trust?

questions.text: Our approach to conflict reflects our care for each other.

therapeutic.rationale: How couples fight reveals how they love. When conflict is handled with care—for the issue and for each other—it demonstrates the relationship's health.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If conflict doesn't reflect care, explore what's happening instead. Often care is present but gets obscured by hurt or defense.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual sense that conflict shows care creates positive framing of disagreements.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does how you fight reflect how you love each other?

questions.text: I feel hopeful about how we'll handle conflicts in the future.

therapeutic.rationale: Hope for future conflict handling reflects confidence in your skills and your partner. This optimism supports continued investment in improving together.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If hope is low, explore what would build it. Specific skill improvements? Different patterns? Understanding what's needed helps create change.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared hope for future conflict creates motivation to keep growing together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you hopeful—or less hopeful—about how you'll handle future conflicts?
